_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Welcome to ‘Council Tax and empty homes’. The third training module in a series of five brought to you by the Scottish Empty Homes Partnership.

We’re halfway through the training program at this stage, which is a good time to reflect on what we have covered so far.

In Module One we gave an introduction to empty homes work. As well as an overview of what the Scottish Empty Homes Partnership high-level aims and objectives are.

In Module Two we honed-in on what empty homes cases consist of and the practices of record keeping and case management.

Module three covers the relationship between empty homes work and Council Tax.

Council Tax data is important to empty homes work and is one of the primary sources of information used by Empty homes officers.

Empty homes officers will use Council Tax data to both proactively engage with owners and investigate any complaints or referrals that come into them.

Within this module, you will learn what empty homes information is contained within Council Tax records and how to access that information.

Here we help you define what a good relationship between you and your local authority's Council Tax department looks like.

Module three explains where everyone fits in as stakeholders and how to develop good working relationships with those stakeholders.

We will take you through case studies, which demonstrate the process of working with Council Tax to reach successful empty homes outcomes.

The Scottish empty homes partnership training is all about you, as we take you through yet another important aspect of empty homes work. We want you to know that we do so because - every home matters.

title: Welcome
body:
Welcome to ‘Council Tax and empty homes’. We are delighted to have you with us here on module three of five on the Scottish Empty Homes Partnership training program.

Council Tax data is vital to empty homes work. It is the primary source of information used by empty homes officers, both to proactively engage owners and investigate complaints/referrals.

Therefore it is important to understand what Council Tax is, how the information stored as Council Tax records can help empty homes work and who the Council Tax department are.

title: Local government finance
body:
The introduction of the Local Government Finance (Unoccupied Properties etc.)(Scotland) Act 2012 resulted in many large scale reviews by local authorities to cleanse the data held on Council Tax records. This was to ensure properties were registered correctly before any proposed changes to their charging policies were made.  

Many long-term empty homes were often on the same Council Tax charging policy as second homes and therefore often incorrectly registered. Before reviews were undertaken, differentiating between empty and second homes was far more difficult. The reviews have altered this picture and there is now more accurate data on the numbers of dwellings registered as empty.

title: Contents
body:
Note: This training module is designed for you to scroll and read articles and interact with content as you do so. You can also navigate between the following pages at any time by using the menu on the top right. There you will also find other helpful resources to support you.

Page one - Home page (video)

  • Home page (video)

Page two - Council Tax and empty homes

  • Why are we looking at Council Tax and what will you learn?
  • What is Council Tax?
  • Scottish Assessors

Page three - Case study and outcomes

Page four - Next steps

title: Practical information
body: Select the images below for more information:

frontImage.alt: How long this training module will take

_items.backBody:
Practical information about this training module:

This module is delivered entirely online and takes an estimated 1-2hrs to complete.

So long as this module remains part of the Scottish Empty Homes Partnership, students will be able to return to use the materials within it as many times as they like.

Your progress is saved should you close and return to the module.

frontImage.alt: Self-serving. Students complete this training module by themselves.

_items.backBody:
Practical information about the overall training program:

The training program is made up of five short online modules.

Students can complete each module and access a certificate of completion without having to submit their work to an assessor.

Certificates are issued by the learning coordinator. Who issues these awards once students have completed the assessment and evaluation questions at the end of each module.

title: Offering discretion
body: Select the images below for more information:

_items.title: Local authorities
_items.body: The ability to vary the charge between 90% and 200% rests with local authorities. It is up to each local authority to decide whether to offer discretion, how it is offered and who administers it.

_items.title: SEHP
_items.body:
SEHP recommend that discretion if offered on a case-by-case basis, and that an empty homes officer is involved in the process, to assess each case on its merits.

We do not advise a blanket approach, i.e. charging everyone who is eligible without offering any discretion, as this has been proven to be a hindrance for owners brining empty homes back into use.

_items.title: The owner
_items.body: Offering discretion allows the owner a chance to bring their property back into use within an agreed timescale, with the levy acting as the incentive for the owner to bring their property back into use as soon as possible, so they do not receive the charge again.

title: What you will learn in this module?
displayTitle: What you will learn in this module?
body:
• The basics of Council Tax
  • What empty homes information is contained within Council Tax records
  • How to access that information
  • Who the Council Tax department are, and what are their priorities 
  • Why developing a good relationship with Council Tax benefits everyone
  • How to work with the Council Tax levy on empty homes
  • What can go wrong with the process.

title: What is Council Tax?
body:
The term ‘council tax’ refers to a tax which is levied on residential properties across the UK. The UK Government advice to households is that there are 3 things they need to know about council tax charges:

  • The valuation band for your home
  • How much your local council charges for that band
  • Whether you can get a discount or exemption  

Council tax charges applied to residential properties vary and in addition to the above will also take into account: property status, the number of people living in it, and occupant’s income.

In Scotland, council tax contributes more than £2 billion towards the funding of local public services annually.

title: Council Tax definitions
body:
The definition used to describe a property is particularly relevant when it is not occupied or used as a main residence. You are most likely to encounter the following categories, in your role with empty homes:

Select through the information in the slides:

_items.title: Unoccupied dwelling
_items.body: An unoccupied dwelling can be either furnished or unfurnished but is not lived in at all or is lived in for less than 25 days in any twelve month period.

_items.title: Long-term empty
_items.body: A long-term empty dwelling can be either furnished or unfurnished but has been registered as unoccupied for a period of 12 months or longer.

_items.title: Second home
_items.body: A dwelling which is furnished and lived in for at least 25 days in any twelve month period, but not as someone’s sole or main residence.

_items.title: Exemption categories
_items.body:
Not all empty properties will be on the Council Tax register under the categories unoccupied dwellings or long-term empty properties. Some empty homes can be exempt from paying Council Tax due to their status.

The timeframes for exemption can vary from set periods or in some instances indefinitely until the situation changes. This can result in properties being empty and exempt for long periods of time. Examples of this are: owners who are in residential care, hospital, or prison, and when properties are being structurally repaired (for up to one year).

title: Component title
body: Note: Remember to ask your Council Tax team to include reports on empty exempt categories, as many of these properties will also be ones that you could bring back into use at some point. They may also be the subject of referrals from the public.

title: Who is responsible for applying council tax charges in Scotland?
displayTitle: Who is responsible for applying council tax charges in Scotland?
body:
The Scottish Government and Scottish Parliament are responsible for the legislation that defines Council Tax.  

Each local authority is responsible for setting the Council Tax rates that apply in their area. They decide how they administer and collect Council Tax and determine how the income generated is used to fund local services provided. However, some revenue is ring fenced. For example, a proportion of the revenue that is generated from second homes and long-term unoccupied properties is reserved for spending that supports the provision of new affordable housing.

title: Scottish Assessors
body:
The Scottish Assessors are responsible for valuing properties and adding/altering/removing them from the Council Tax register. Their website is a useful data source, it provides details of all Council Tax bandings for properties across Scotland and also details of premises on Rates register.   

Based on its relative property value they assign each property in Scotland one of eight valuation bands, from A (lowest) to H (highest).  

The local authorities use these valuation bands and apply a scale to Council Tax charges applied.  

Note: open-up the example in the resources area titled ‘Council Tax charges’ to carry out a small activity.

title: Properties not on the Council Tax register
displayTitle: Properties not on the Council Tax register
body:
Not all empty properties that you investigate will be on the Council Tax register.

Some residential properties may be registered for Business Rates dependent on their registered use.

Select through all the hotspots on the image to reveal further information:

_graphic.alt: Illustration of home in state of disrepair

_items.title: Self-catering unit / holiday lets
_items.body:
These are premises that are made available for letting on a commercial basis as self-catering accommodation for short periods amounting in aggregate to more than 140 days per year. The full definition and information can be found in the Scottish Assessors Association (SAA) practice note:  

https://www.saa.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Self-Catering-Units_R2017_CPC17.pdf

_items.title: Premises under repair, refurbishment or reconstruction
_items.body:
If works are substantial and dictate that the premises are not capable of beneficial occupation they may be added as premises with nil value and appear in Rates. See link to SAA practice below for further information:   

https://www.saa.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/dlm_uploads/2019/01/Properties-Under-Repair-etc._R2017_BPC03.pdf  

Check the SAA website in the first instance to determine if property is on the business rates register: https://www.saa.gov.uk/
_items.strapline: Premises under repair, refurbishment or reconstruction

_items.title: Properties that do not show on either register
_items.body:
In some rare cases, there may be properties that do not show on either the Council Tax or business rates register. In these instances, old property records and the land registry are sources of tracing owners.  

The SEHP have created a Data Collection Guide which is available to help you review the full sources available to you when tracing owners. 

Note: you can view SEHP’s Data Collection Guide in the resources area
_items.strapline: Properties that do not show on either register

title: Council Tax guidance – unoccupied properties
body:
There have been a significant number of changes to the guidance in relation to Council Tax discounts for long-term empty and second homes in recent years.  

The Local Government Finance (Unoccupied Properties etc.) (Scotland) Act 2012 and subsequent regulations, provides provision for local authorities to remove the discount and increase the level payable on certain types of unoccupied homes. This legislation is a resource to encourage owners to bring homes back into use and not leave empty for long periods of time.  

The legislation gives councils the discretion to vary the Council Tax payable on unoccupied properties. Initially a discount of between 10% and 50% must be provided, but after a property is unoccupied for 12 months (or 24 months if being actively marketed for sale or let), an increase of up to 100% may be imposed.

Note: you can view access further information on the Local Government Finance (Unoccupied Properties etc.) (Scotland) Act 2012 and Scottish Government guidance on discretion in the resources area.

title: Component title
body:
SEHP recommend that additional revenue raised via the levy is spent on supporting empty homeowners to bring their properties back into use, preferably with a dedicated empty homes service within the council but also with loans, grants etc. 

The Council Tax levy is both a positive and a negative influence on empty homes work depending on how it is applied.

title: Opportunities and risks
body: Select through the information in the slides:

_items.title: Opportunities
_items.body:
• Encourages owners/liable parties of long-term empty homes to act rather than continue to leave empty
  • Owners more likely to engage and receive advice and assistance to help make informed choices
  • Use of discretion as a carrot can focus owners to bring their properties back into use within an agreed timescale.

_items.title: Risks
_items.body:
• Use of the levy as a blanket charge, i.e. a stick without a carrot, may cause owners to be financially unable to bring their property back into use
  • Owners may seek to avoid the levy by fraudulently claiming the property is a second home or occupied when it is in fact still empty.

Note: a previous owner or occupier's use of the property can affect how much discount the new owner or occupier’s may be eligible to receive and for how long.

_graphic.alt: Illustration of a house with cross overlaying it

title: Task
body: Find out what rates of Council Tax your local authority charges for long-term empty homes.

title: Agreeing working practices
body:
If the Empty Homes Officer and Council Tax staff, both have a clear understanding on each other’s key objectives and the benefits of working together, it will make the process of agreeing working practices more meaningful and effective.

There are many examples of good practice which demonstrate effective partnership working. You may wish to suggest initially setting out joint working agreement and protocols for: 

  • Obtaining read only access to Council Tax system
  • Report templates – timescales/information required
  • Information sharing and Data Cleansing procedures
  • Joint update meeting intervals
  • Referral system to Empty Homes Officer i.e. include contact details for advice on all Council Tax correspondence in relation long-term empty homes
  • If applicable, procedures for applying discretion to long-term empty homes subject to premium charge (i.e. approval and monitoring procedures)
  • Who makes the decision and what frequency of engagement/inspections are required?

title: Tasks
body:
Find out what the overarching key objectives are for the Council Tax department in your local authority.

Make a note to clarify your Council Tax departments key aims and objectives at your induction meeting if you have one.

title: Working with Council Tax information
body:
The relationship Empty Homes Officers have with their Council Tax colleagues is paramount to ensuring that they have access to the data required to fulfil duties.  

We need Council Tax information to be able to work proactively and it is the most valuable resource of information available to an Empty Homes Officer. 

Section 157, of the Housing Scotland Act (2010), provides a provision for Empty Homes Officers to have read only access to Council Tax records. 

The information held on Council Tax records can be of significant use to assist with investigations into the circumstances of an empty home and the options to bring it back into use.

title: Information that can be gained
body:
• Owner/s or responsible party’s name/s
  • Contact information – address, email, telephone numbers
  • How long it has been registered empty
  • History of property – was it registered as empty prior to existing owners purchasing, has it had many different owners etc
  • Information obtained from discount/exemption application forms – such as condition of property, any on-going works, proposed timescales etc.

title: Building good relations
body:
By making early contact and building a rapport with colleagues in Council Tax from the offset can help cement good healthy working relationships.

There are clear advantages for Empty Homes Officer to have access to Council Tax information for investigating empty properties. However, the Empty Homes Officer can be an equally valuable resource to the Council Tax Department and wider team. These benefits will assist you to demonstrate the value of joint working when you meet with Council Tax colleagues.

title: Gardner Street, Glasgow
body:
How long has the property been empty, in total?  

24 years - Since 1995 according to Council Tax records, there may have been squatters in the interim 

When did the Empty Homes Officer (EHO) first contact the owner?  

Initial referral received on 24 July 2018 and eventually managed to trace owner using Fraser & Fraser, Genealogists in October 2018 

How did the EHO first become aware of this empty home?                            

Member of the public reported an open back window to Glasgow City Council Land & Environmental Services who passed to EHO

title: The property
body:
In which local authority area is the property located?  

Glasgow City 

What type of property is it?  

Tenement Flat 

Why did the property initially become empty?  

Tenants moved out and owner did not occupy 

Why did the property then remain empty?  

Disinterest / personal issues

title: Empty Homes Officer actions
body:
What options were available to the EHO?  

EHO visited property and talked to neighbours looking for anecdotal evidence, phoned Police Scotland but no information could be disclosed, contacted colleagues in other GCC departments, but all drew a blank on forwarding address. 

EHO contacted Fraser & Fraser and they found contact details for owner. I telephoned owner and discovered there were severe personal and medical issues which prevented them from visiting the property, however, they were aware that it was accruing massive council tax and factors debts and didn’t know where to start in sorting it out. 

How was the EHO able to help?  

In May 2019, after months of contact by letter and phone, owner agreed to come to Glasgow to meet with EHO and Auction House Scotland.  However, this meeting was cancelled on the day by the owner, as he had received an unsolicited offer for the property which was substantially less than what it was worth, but owner was prepared to accept.  EHO advised against accepting this offer before speaking to another property professional and asked for permission to discuss with AHS which was given.  EHO spoke with John Loudon (AHS) who confirmed that the offer was less than the value of the flat and offered to speak to owner.  John Loudon went to Gourock to meet with owner who subsequently agreed AHS terms and the flat was sold with an increased offer and the sale concluded on 26 July 2019. 

Were there any obstacles in this case, and if so how were they overcome?  

Owner lived out with Glasgow and was primary carer for partner with Alzheimers.  

Did you work with any partners in this case?  

Auction House Scotland

title: Outcome
body:
What was the outcome in this case?  

 

Flat was sold and the owner paid Glasgow City Council £32,765.84 in outstanding council tax charges  

If the outcome was Property Sold, was the property ready to move into, or did it require further work to render it habitable?  

No major renovation was required

title: Council Tax
body:
At what rate is council tax being charged on this property?  

200% 

Are there council tax arrears on this property?  

£32,765.84 – which were paid in full

title: Data cleansing and sharing
body:
Data cleansing is ensuring that the information held is up to date and accurate. This is usually done by the owner updating information or by council tax account reviews.  

If the Empty Homes Officer is engaged with the owners/liable parties, they can check information held is accurate and if necessary, update accordingly. This can help Council Tax maintain records, that they usually don’t have the resource to do themselves.  

The Empty Homes Officers are also out on site and able to go and visually inspect properties (when safe to do so) and verify status. For example, the Empty Homes Officer may receive report of an empty property which is registered as a second home on Council Tax.

title: Signposting to Empty Homes Officer
body:
One of key functions of the Empty Homes Officer is to provide owners/liable parties with advice on the options to bring their homes back into use. Council Tax colleagues could refer customers directly for assistance. This not only provides customers with a better service but can help to mitigate and reduce the number of enquiries and complaints received in relation to charging policy for long-term empty properties etc.   

There may also be more likelihood of a commitment from the owners/liable parties to pay Council Tax due on empty property when they are engaged and discussing financial resources with Empty Homes Officer.  

Our experience of this relationship in practice suggests that the best results occur when council tax proactively engage owners prior to the council tax levy taking place. One suggestion might be to include the empty homes officer’s details on the back of every letter that council tax send out to owners affected by the levy. 

You should get to know the set up the team; are there separate Debt Recovery and Fraud Departments? If so, make sure you introduce yourself to each department, there are likely to be cases where the benefit of joint working with the wider team will provide better outcomes for all involved.

title: What are the obstacles when dealing with owners?
displayTitle: What are the obstacles when dealing with owners?
body:
• Council tax levy (may need discretion or could be incorrectly calculated)
  • Incorrect category (holiday home/closing order etc)
  • Council tax debt may cause reluctance to engage/sell, if amount recouped once debt is repaid would not be significant.

title: Review process
body:
Any of the above issues could cause an owner to ask for their case to be looked at in more detail. This normally starts with a review, followed by an appeal if the owner disagrees with the conclusion of the review. 

An owner could ask for a review themselves, but a review could also come via a third party, such as SEHP or Citizens Advice Bureau. If an owner asks SEHP for help with their Council Tax case, we will always contact the empty homes officer for that area first and will encourage them to assist the owner, with our support. 

If there is no empty homes officer in the area, we will support the owner directly. We always encourage owners to maintain a cordial and constructive dialogue with council tax and seek cases reviewed on the basis of legislation and Scottish Government guidance. If you are undertaking a review on behalf of an owner, please do contact SEHP for guidance. 

If the result of the review process is not satisfactory to the owner, they may then appeal. Appeals are heard by the Valuation Appeal Committee, who look at the determination and calculation of Council Tax liability.

Share on Twitter

title: Council Tax Department
body:
It is crucial to understand that whilst there are overlapping interests, the overarching priorities of Council Tax Department may be slightly different from the aims and objectives that you as an Empty Homes Officer are trying to achieve.

Nonetheless the relationship between council tax and empty homes, together with the benefits of working together help forge agreed priorities and protocols.

Objectives for the Council Tax (Finance) Department  

Likely to include a focus on areas such as: 

  • Collecting council tax
  • Providing an effective and response customer service
  • Maintaining accurate records
  • Billing schedules
  • Maximising recovery rates to sustain funding streams.

title: Accurate information and updated accounts
body:
There is a reliance and legal obligation on owners/responsible parties to provide accurate information and to update accounts timeously when there is a change in circumstances.  

Council Tax staff generally do not have the resources to monitor and investigate information provided unless this forms part of a standard review etc. In relation to empty properties this can be one of the key advantages of having a good joint working relationship between Empty Homes Officer and Council Tax Department.  

You can be the resource that they are missing, to investigate empty homes cases.
